name: René Descartes
bio: A French philosopher, mathematician, and scientist, often regarded as the father of modern philosophy.

arguments.title: Cogito, ergo sum
arguments.description: The foundation of Descartes' philosophy, asserting self-awareness as undeniable.
arguments.summary: I think, therefore I am. This argument establishes the certainty of one's own existence through the act of thinking.
arguments.realLifeExample: Even if you doubt everything else, the very act of doubting confirms your existence as a thinking being.
arguments.pro: Provides a clear starting point for building knowledge based on certainty.
arguments.con: Critiqued for being too introspective and not addressing the existence of the external world.

arguments.title: Dualism
arguments.description: The belief in two fundamental substances: mind and matter.
arguments.summary: Dualism posits that the mind and body are distinct and separable entities, with the mind being non-material.
arguments.realLifeExample: Your thoughts and consciousness exist independently of your physical body.
arguments.pro: Explains the subjective experience and consciousness.
arguments.con: Struggles to explain the interaction between mind and body.

influence: His work laid the groundwork for rationalism and influenced subsequent philosophers like Spinoza and Leibniz.

name: Immanuel Kant
bio: A German philosopher who is a central figure in modern philosophy.
works: Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals

arguments.title: Categorical Imperative
arguments.description: A central principle in Kant's deontological moral philosophy.
arguments.summary: Act only according to that maxim whereby you can, at the same time, will that it should become a universal law.
arguments.realLifeExample: If you consider lying to get out of trouble, you must imagine a world where everyone lies in similar situations, which would undermine trust.
arguments.pro: Provides a clear and universal basis for moral actions.
arguments.con: Can be rigid and may not account for complex moral dilemmas.

arguments.title: Transcendental Idealism
arguments.description: Kant's theory on the nature of reality and human perception.
arguments.summary: Asserts that our experience of things is about how they appear to us, not about those things as they are in themselves.
arguments.realLifeExample: We perceive a tree's color based on our sensory input, not necessarily the tree's inherent color independent of our perception.
arguments.pro: Bridges rationalism and empiricism, accounting for human perception.
arguments.con: Leaves the nature of things-in-themselves obscure and unknowable.

influence: His critical philosophy bridged rationalism and empiricism, influencing German Idealism and contemporary philosophy.

name: Aristotle
bio: An ancient Greek philosopher and polymath, student of Plato and teacher of Alexander the Great.

arguments.title: Golden Mean
arguments.description: A key concept in Aristotle's virtue ethics.
arguments.summary: Virtue lies between two extremes of excess and deficiency, promoting moderation.
arguments.realLifeExample: Courage is the balance between recklessness (excess) and cowardice (deficiency).
arguments.con: Determining the exact mean can be subjective and context-dependent.

arguments.title: Four Causes
arguments.description: Aristotle's explanation of why things exist as they do.
arguments.summary: Includes material, formal, efficient, and final causes to explain an object's existence and purpose.
arguments.realLifeExample: A wooden table: material cause (wood), formal cause (design), efficient cause (carpenter), final cause (to hold items).
arguments.pro: Provides a comprehensive framework for understanding causality.
arguments.con: Modern science often requires more precise explanations beyond the four causes.

influence: His works laid the foundation for Western philosophy and science, influencing countless scholars through the centuries.

name: Plato
bio: An ancient Greek philosopher, student of Socrates, and teacher of Aristotle.

arguments.title: Theory of Forms
arguments.description: Plato's metaphysical theory explaining the nature of reality.
arguments.summary: Non-material abstract forms, and not the material world, possess the highest and most fundamental kind of reality.
arguments.realLifeExample: A perfect circle exists in the realm of forms, while any drawn circle is merely an imperfect copy.
arguments.pro: Explains the universality and perfection of concepts and objects.
arguments.con: Difficult to explain how forms interact with the physical world.

arguments.title: Allegory of the Cave
arguments.description: A metaphor for human perception and enlightenment.
arguments.summary: Humans are like prisoners in a cave who see only shadows of real objects, mistaking appearances for reality.
arguments.realLifeExample: Educational enlightenment as breaking free from ignorance to understand the true nature of reality.
arguments.pro: Illustrates the journey from ignorance to knowledge and the importance of education.
arguments.con: Critiqued for being overly pessimistic about human perception.

influence: Plato's ideas have shaped Western thought, politics, and education for over two millennia.

name: Søren Kierkegaard
bio: A Danish philosopher, social critic, and theologian, often considered the first existentialist philosopher.

arguments.title: Leap of Faith
arguments.description: Kierkegaard's concept of believing without empirical evidence.
arguments.summary: To believe in something transcendent, such as God, one must make a subjective leap of faith beyond rational understanding.
arguments.realLifeExample: Choosing to believe in a higher power despite the lack of scientific proof.
arguments.pro: Emphasizes personal commitment and the importance of individual belief.
arguments.con: Critiqued for potentially encouraging irrational belief systems.

arguments.title: Existential Angst
arguments.description: The feeling of deep anxiety arising from human freedom and responsibility.
arguments.summary: Angst is the realization of one's absolute freedom to choose, leading to feelings of dread and uncertainty.
arguments.realLifeExample: Feeling overwhelmed by the responsibility of making life-altering decisions.
arguments.pro: Highlights the importance of personal responsibility and authenticity.
arguments.con: Can be seen as perpetuating feelings of despair and meaninglessness.

influence: His emphasis on individual existence and personal choice laid the groundwork for existentialism and modern theology.

name: Friedrich Nietzsche
bio: A German philosopher, cultural critic, poet, and philologist whose work has exerted a profound influence on Western philosophy and modern intellectual history.

arguments.title: Übermensch (Overman/Superman)
arguments.description: Nietzsche's idea of an individual who has transcended conventional morality to create their own values.
arguments.summary: The Übermensch represents the goal for humanity to set their own values and purpose, overcoming the limitations of traditional societal norms.
arguments.realLifeExample: An artist or thinker who creates groundbreaking work that redefines cultural or moral standards.
arguments.pro: Encourages personal growth, creativity, and the rejection of herd mentality.
arguments.con: Critiqued for promoting elitism and disregarding communal values.

arguments.title: Will to Power
arguments.description: The fundamental driving force in humans to assert and enhance their power and influence.
arguments.summary: Nietzsche posits that the primary motivation in humans is the 'will to power'—a desire to reach the highest possible position in life.
arguments.realLifeExample: An entrepreneur striving to build a successful business empire.
arguments.pro: Explains ambition and the drive for success in human behavior.
arguments.con: Can be interpreted as endorsing domination and exploitation.

influence: His provocative ideas challenged the foundations of Christianity and traditional morality, influencing a wide range of philosophical, artistic, and political movements.
